head.headtext: Communications between law enforcement officers and peer counselors

para.paratext: The legislature enacted O.C.G.A. § 24-5-510 in 2014. The statute provides that law enforcement officers and their immediate families may have privileged communications with peer counselors. Peer counselors must be employees of law enforcement agencies, designated by the head of the agency, who have received training to provide emotional and moral support to fellow workers and their families.

Communications shared are privileged unless the disclosure is approved by the client, it is compelled by a court order, the peer counselor was an initial responding officer, witness or party to an act that is the subject of the counseling, the communication was made when the counselor was not performing official duties, or if the client is charged with a crime.[1]

Given the exceptions, the author would caution clients from engaging in these types of communications, since the statute provides such a wide range of ways to obtain what are purported to be confidential and privileged communications.
